prediction: An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) was recommended to place a common bile duct stent to allow drainage of the biliary obstruction caused by stones and sludge. Due to no improvement in liver function, a repeat ERCP was needed. The repeat ERCP showed the biliary stent was obstructed by sludge and stones. A sphincterotomy was safely performed to remove the stones and stent.

The patient was given Lasix for acute diastolic heart failure with symptoms including shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. He was given 8 liters of fluid to help maintain his blood pressure which contributed to his respiratory failure. After treatment with Lasix, he showed improvement in symptoms and only needed a small amount of supplemental oxygen for comfort.

The patient should expect drowsiness, headaches, dizziness, irritability, and short-term memory loss after his head injury. These symptoms are normal and will decrease over the next few weeks. He should follow up with a specialist and report any visual changes, weakness on one side, or speech difficulty.
